faculty.address:
Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: The first part of the course is on the univariate GARCH models and their estimation. The second part of the course is on multivariate GARCH models and their estimation. The third part of the course is on univariate and multivariate Stochastic Volatility models and estimation. The fourth part is on Value at Risk and Expected Shortfall. The last part of the course is on how different volatility models can be compared in terms of performance after estimation.
description.et: Kursuse esimene osa katab ühe-dimensioonilisi GARCH mudeleid ja nende hindamist. Kursuse teine osa on mitmedimensioonilistest GARCH mudelitest ja nende hindamisest. Kursuse kolmas osa on ühe ja mitmemõõtmelistest volatiilsuse mudelitest ja nende hindamisest. Kursuse neljas osa on riskiväärtusest (Value at Risk) ja oodatavast puudujäägist (Expected Shortfall). Kursuse viimane osa on erinevate volatiilsuse mudelite hindamise edukusest.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to give students overview of the univariate and multivariate GARCH and SV models and their estimation.
objectives.et: Õppeaine eesmärk on anda üliõpilastele ülevaade GARCH mudelitest ja stohhastilise volatiilsuse (SV) mudelitest ning nende hindamistest.

learning_outcomes.en: After taking the course students will know about the univariate and multivariate models of volatility; estimation and forecasting of volatilities, covolatilities and correlations between series; how to write a program in Matlab on estimation and forecasting volatility models.
learning_outcomes.et: Pärast kursuse läbimist üliõpilane tunneb ühemõõtmelisi ja mitmemõõtmelisi volatiilsuse mudeleid; oskab hinnata ja ennustada volatiilsusi, kaasvolatiilsusi ja korrelatsioone aegridade vahel; kuidas kirjutada programmi Matlabis volatiilsuse mudelite hindamiseks ja volatiilsuse ennustamiseks.

notes.et: The final evaluation in this course will be based on a term project. The details will be provided during the course.

description.et: Evaluation will be done by a term project. The details will be provided during the course. To pass the course the student needs to receive at least 51 points from the term project.
Stylized facts about financial returns and volatility, stationarity, autoregressive and moving average models
Computer examples of return calculation and fitting ARMA models to returns. Interpreting estimation output.
Univariate ARCH and GARCH models. Distribution assumptions for the ARMA error term. Maximum likelihood estimation.
Computer examples of ARMA-GARCH estimations. Interpreting estimation output.
Univariate and multivariate extensions of GARCH models.
Computer examples of extensions of GARCH models. Interpretation and presentation of results.
Further computer examples with real data. Focus will be on multivariate GARCH models.
Value at risk (VaR) and expected shortfall (ES). Use of VaR and ES for model evaluation.
